[2]It is true.

dialogues.Thomas:
[1]I've heard bad things, Paul. My assistant says we should get out of Rwanda. 
[2]What good is it if we are murdered in our bed? 
[3]Yes, and he is in the Hutu Power Militia. 
[4]No, he is a friend, but he tells me to listen to the radio. All day they talk about the great slaughter. 
[5]Forgive us, Paul. We must talk. 
[6]We are leaving Rwanda, Paul. 
[7]My assistant, the Hutu Power man, says we should get out now, that soon it will be very bad. 
[8]His name is Naramaranga, but please, Paul, even though he is Hutu Power, he is a friend, he likes me. He told me there is a signal. It is "Cut the tall trees." When they hear the signal, the militia are to go to war. 
[9]Please, Paul, tomorrow I will bring you my car. You will sell it for me and get a fair price. We will go to Tanzania until there is real peace.

[395]Please witness this deed. 
[396]There, now go and find them. They have no papers. No one knows they are Tutsi. They will be alive.

[399]Zozo you are family, join us.

[412]I will follow on the next plane. Go.

[415]Dear lord, how did they know? 
[416]When? 
[417]Please, General, I will give you money, whiskey. 
[418]Please, I have money. They're driving into an ambush, it's on the radio. 
[419]Thank God you are safe.

[422]You will get it in due time. Now, please, get back to the gate.

[426]No. We have no way of finding other stock but I have money for you from the guests.

[428]Get down there and stop them, please. 
[429]Get down and stop them. 
[430]What do you mean you cannot shoot? 
[431]Then go and pretend you are soldiers. 
[432]We are almost out of everything. 
[433]We had a good life, you and I. I want to make our peace. To thank God for the time we had. 
[434]We have to have a plan.

[437]The machete is no way to die. Promise me you will do it.

[447] Tatiana is beside him. He opens the envelope, finds his makeshift house deed and a note.  
[448]It's from Garandi. I am sorry. There is no hope for the twins. The old lady's house has been destroyed. 
[449] Paul sleeps fitfully. It is almost dawn, then he sits up.  
[450]The Diplomat! 
[451]I have to go to the Diplomat. 
[452]General, sir. I am glad to find you. I have found you some supplies.

[464]

[474]

dialogues.Colonel:
[1]Our intelligence, Mr. Ambassador, is that the Hutu government has been stockpiling weapons and are preparing a massacre. 
[2]How about a battalion of U.S. Marines. 
[3]You're right, Mr. Ambassador, Paul knows how to get anything, even U.S. troops. 
[4]To Peace. 
[5]Paul, you know who this is? 
[6]Get him a room, but tell no one he is here. Paul will look after you. 
[7]No. But I fear it's intention may have been to kill the peace accords and spark a civil war between the Hutu Militia and the Tutsi rebels. 
[8]Unfortunately we're here as peace-keepers not peace makers, we can't take an aggressive role. 
[9]Yes. With some re-inforcements I'm confident we could impose order. 
[10]Yes we have. 
[11]We're awaiting a decision, excuse me. 
[12]Paul, I've sent my soldiers to rescue the Lady Prime Minister, she'll need a room. 
[13]I'm sorry, I can't possibly take them Paul. I'm overrun with refugees. As soon as we can stabilize the situation we'll take them. 
[14]Hold the line here. Do not shoot! 
[15]They murdered my soldiers. Ten Belgians who I sent to get the lady minister. 
[16]You have a battalion, you could stop this now. The Hutu army is no match for you. 
[17]You will remember this day for the rest of your lives. 
[18]Anything. Strong. 
[19] 
[20]We think you are dirt, less than dirt, worthless. 
[21]Don't bullshit me, Paul. You're the smartest man here. You have them all eating out of your hand. You'd own this fucking hotel, except for one thing. 
[22]You're fucking black! You're not even a nigger, you're African! They're not staying to stop this thing. They're gonna fly right out of here with their people. 
[23]They're only taking the whites. 
[24]Great news, Paul, we're going to get you out of here. 
[25]The UN has been notified that the following families have received travel visas from the following countries. 
[26]Abukesu - Tanzania, Arumangu -Zambia, Bawroanga - Kenya, 
[27]Gituaranga - Zambi, Horangora - Belguim 
[28]Paramisambi - Zambia, Rusesabagina - Belgium. 
[29]Zamacanga - Ghana. A plane will land at the airport tomorrow and the named families will be flown to Kenya. Two UN trucks will be here at 7 a.m. The named families must be ready to leave then. 
[30]I can't do that. Our camp at the airport is overwhelmed already. We could not defend you there. You are better to stay here and work to get an exit visa. 
[31]Paul, only those I called can get on the trucks. I do not want to have to pull people off, you understand? 
[32]Yes.   Where are the Rwandan police? 
[33]That explains it. I'm sorry to tell you this but we've heard rumors the Militia are getting ready to storm the hotel. 
[34]I can't, I don't have the men. 
[35]There's one option. 
[36]The rebels have fought their way into the city. They have many Hutu prisoners. They're willing to exchange them for you all. 
[37]I think so. They are in disarray now. The rebels are winning, and the Hutu high command are anxious to get some of their men back. 
[38]By convoy. 
[39]A man came to my headquarters, asked that I give you this. 
[40]Paul, I need you to buy me a day or two. I don't have the fuel for this convoy. I will have to scrounge it. 
[41]No, Paul, they're afraid. They've demanded to be moved back to headquarters now. 
[42]I wish I could, Paul. Try to hold out. One more day. 
[43]Don't stop. Push through. 
[44]Keep going.

[56] 
[57] 
[58]So where is the lamb?

[61]Go out! Where?

[94] The bodies move, look up, it's not them. It's refugees hiding. Paul, delirious with fear, runs along the parapet.  BELOW he sees soldiers herding the Militia.  He runs back to the stairs.  INSIDE THE STAIRCASE: He jumps four stairs at a time.  INSIDE THE CORRIDOR: Soldiers are chasing off the Militia.  TO HIS ROOM: Paul staggers in, crazed with fear. He looks under the bed.  INTO THE BATHROOM - empty.  He's about to run out again, sees the connecting door to the adjoining hotel room is slightly open.     INTO THE ADJOINING ROOM: It's empty, then A WHIMPER.  FROM THE BATHROOM, he moves in, cautious.  IN THE BATHROOM: Nothing. He moves over, pulls back the shower curtain.  Reveals: A cluster of women and children, the older ones holding hands over the mouths of the younger ones. And there at the back: Tatiana and his kids.

dialogues.Policeman: [1]Mr. Rusesabagina, good morning.  In the passenger seat PAUL RUSESABAGINA, late 30's, flashes a smile. He is dressed in a sharp blue suit (always dressed in a neat suit and tie, it is a matter of pride).  A quick shake of hands. Money passes from one to the other.
dialogues.General:
[1]Paul, this scotch is exceptional. 
[2]Oh, Paul, talk to the coat check, please. 
[3] 
[4]Of course, the president is a clever man, he knows what he is doing. Thank you for coming to Rwanda. . You will see what a beautiful country this is. 
[5]Keep that cockroach Benedict away from me. 
[6]Paul, join us. 
[7]Have a drink. 
[8]I am glad you are well. 
[9]As long as it is scotch. Your white friends have abandoned you, Paul. 
[10]The United Nations. Madmen are on the streets, Paul. But I will take care of you.  Your cellar is well-stocked, right? 
[11]What did you overhear? 
[12]What did they say? 
[13]Watch everything? How? They are gone. 
[14]Satellites? 
[15]The high command? Our high command? 
[16]The Americans! Who are they to put us on trial. Let us imagine Paul when their president Kennedy was shot, they said it was a black man. Then their politicians, their radio stations gave orders `we must wipe out these black people before they wipe out us.' What do you think would have happened? No different. 
[17]The police are very busy. 
[18]He did. 
[19]If I were to spare a few policemen, where would I station them? 
[20]I will see what I can do. 
[21]I am strong, Paul, like a lion. 
[22]Get to work, you slug. 
[23]Make sure, Paul, your guests are generous. 
[24]You said you had no whiskey. 
[25]Come here. 
[26]Where are my supplies? 
[27]You have cockroaches dancing on tables and you tell me the cellar is empty? Did they drink my whiskey? 
[28]Rwandan francs! They are only good now for wiping your ass. There is nothing more I can do for you people. No police. No protection. You're on your own.

[30]I'll be over. 
[31]Get in. 
[32]After the Diplomat! 
[33]They can go where they want. They are in charge now.

[35]Today. 
[36]Maggots! 
[37]Do your work. 
[38]Here.  To celebrate.

[42]Pack those carefully, put them in my jeep, and guard them. 
[43]I am going to do you a great favor. I am going to take you with us to Gitarama.

[45]We are better here.

[48]You lie. 
[49]I committed no war crimes. 
[50]I led no massacres. 
[51]You will tell them I did nothing. 
[52]Get back!  Get them out of here.

dialogues.Rutaganda:
[1] At his desk in front of a fan. GEORGE RUTAGUNDA, late 30's, huge, gold chains, Rolex watch,  but the same Interahamwe shirt. He squeezes an orange rind into a cup of espresso.  Behind him, through his office window, the white van is being loaded with cases of beer.  George holds out his massive shirt.  
[2] The fog still hangs like a cloud. As they pull up, a group of young Militia emerge from Toyota trucks.  
[3] The warehouse is filled with looted televisions, artwork, cars. George points to the stacks of beer.
